lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: This is so much trickier than it sounds, it's not even funny.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: According to RFC 3023 ('XML Media Types'), if the HTTP Content-Type
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: the encoding given in the charset parameter of the HTTP Content-Type
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: takes precedence over the encoding given in the XML prefix within the
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: document, and defaults to 'utf-8' if neither are specified.  But, if
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: the HTTP Content-Type is text/xml, text/*+xml, or
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: text/xml-external-parsed-entity, the encoding given in the XML prefix
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: within the document is ALWAYS IGNORED and only the encoding given in
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: the charset parameter of the HTTP Content-Type header should be
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: respected, and it defaults to 'us-ascii' if not specified.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: Furthermore, discussion on the atom-syntax mailing list with the
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: author of RFC 3023 leads me to the conclusion that any document
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: served with a Content-Type of text/* and no charset parameter
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: must be treated as us-ascii.  (We now do this.)  And also that it
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: must always be flagged as non-well-formed.  (We now do this too.)
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: If Content-Type is unspecified (input was local file or non-HTTP source)
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: or unrecognized (server just got it totally wrong), then go by the
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: encoding given in the XML prefix of the document and default to
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: Then, assuming we didn't find a character encoding in the HTTP headers
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: (and the HTTP Content-type allowed us to look in the body), we need
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: to sniff the first few bytes of the XML data and try to determine
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: whether the encoding is ASCII-compatible.  Section F of the XML
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: If the sniffed encoding is not ASCII-compatible, we need to make it
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: ASCII compatible so that we can sniff further into the XML declaration
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: to find the encoding attribute, which will tell us the true encoding.
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: Of course, none of this guarantees that we will be able to parse the
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: feed in the declared character encoding (assuming it was declared
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: correctly, which many are not).  iconv_codec can help a lot;
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: you should definitely install it if you can.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: '''takes HTTP Content-Type header and returns (content type, charset)
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: If no charset is specified, returns (content type, '')
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: If no content type is specified, returns ('', '')
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: Both return parameters are guaranteed to be lowercase strings
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # Must sniff for non-ASCII-compatible character encodings before
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # searching for XML declaration.  This heuristic is defined in
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # section F of the XML specification:
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # In all forms of EBCDIC, these four bytes correspond
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # to the string '<?xm'; try decoding using CP037
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: if sniffed_xml_encoding and (xml_encoding in (u'iso-10646-ucs-2', u'ucs-2', u'csunicode', u'iso-10646-ucs-4', u'ucs-4', u'csucs4', u'utf-16', u'utf-32', u'utf_16', u'utf_32', u'utf16', u'u16')):
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: true_encoding = http_encoding or xml_encoding or u'utf-8'
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: elif http_headers and 'content-type' not in http_headers:
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # some feeds claim to be gb2312 but are actually gb18030.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # apparently MSIE and Firefox both do the following switch:
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: return true_encoding, http_encoding, xml_encoding, sniffed_xml_encoding, acceptable_content_type
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: '''Changes an XML data stream on the fly to specify a new encoding
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: data is a raw sequence of bytes (not Unicode) that is presumed to be in %encoding already
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: encoding is a string recognized by encodings.aliases
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: '''Strips DOCTYPE from XML document, returns (rss_version, stripped_data)
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: stripped_data is the same XML document, minus the DOCTYPE
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # only allow in 'safe' inline entity definitions
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: return version, data, dict(replacement and [(k.decode('utf-8'), v.decode('utf-8')) for k, v in safe_pattern.findall(replacement)])
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: def parse(url_file_stream_or_string, etag=None, modified=None, agent=None, referrer=None, handlers=None, request_headers=None, response_headers=None):
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: '''Parse a feed from a URL, file, stream, or string.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: request_headers, if given, is a dict from http header name to value to add
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: to the request; this overrides internally generated values.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: f = _open_resource(url_file_stream_or_string, etag, modified, agent, referrer, handlers, request_headers)
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # lowercase all of the HTTP headers for comparisons per RFC 2616
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: http_headers = dict((k.lower(), v) for k, v in result['headers'].items())
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # if feed is gzip-compressed, decompress it
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if f and data and http_headers:
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # IOError can occur if the gzip header is bad.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # struct.error can occur if the data is damaged.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # A gzip header was found but the data is corrupt.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Ideally, we should re-request the feed without the
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # The data may have no headers and no checksum.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # there are four encodings to keep track of:
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # - http_encoding is the encoding declared in the Content-Type HTTP header
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # - xml_encoding is the encoding declared in the <?xml declaration
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # - sniffed_encoding is the encoding sniffed from the first 4 bytes of the XML data
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # - result['encoding'] is the actual encoding, as per RFC 3023 and a variety of other conflicting specifications
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: bozo_message = '%s is not an XML media type' % http_headers['content-type']
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # ensure that baseuri is an absolute uri using an acceptable URI scheme
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: if not isinstance(baselang, unicode) and baselang is not None:
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: result['debug_message'] = 'The feed has not changed since you last checked, ' + \
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: 'so the server sent no data.  This is a feature, not a bug!'
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # if there was a problem downloading, we're done
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # try: HTTP encoding, declared XML encoding, encoding sniffed from BOM
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: # if no luck and we have auto-detection library, try that
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if proposed_encoding and (proposed_encoding not in tried_encodings):
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # if still no luck and we haven't tried utf-8 yet, try that
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if (not known_encoding) and (u'utf-8' not in tried_encodings):
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # if still no luck and we haven't tried windows-1252 yet, try that
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: if (not known_encoding) and (u'windows-1252' not in tried_encodings):
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # if still no luck and we haven't tried iso-8859-2 yet, try that.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: if (not known_encoding) and (u'iso-8859-2' not in tried_encodings):
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # if still no luck, give up
lines.author: tomdesmedt@gmail.com@b69ec992-5447-3b6c-d919-7ed00d13665f

lines.code: '%s, %s, utf-8, windows-1252, and iso-8859-2 but nothing worked' % \
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # disable downloading external doctype references, if possible
lines.author: tom@organisms.be
